p: A comprehensive picture of the viruses shed in the feces of 25 healthy cats from a shelter in China ( Zhang et al., 2014a, Zhang et al., 2014b) has identified either complete or partial viral genomes of astroviruses, bocaparvoviruses, and cycloviruses. The near complete genome sequences of three astrovirus strains, D1, D2, and D3, were obtained ( Zhang et al., 2014a, Zhang et al., 2014b), with strain D1 being distantly related to other feline astroviruses ( Lau et al., 2013, Ng et al., 2014). In the same study, the nearly complete genomes of two bocaparvovirus strains, FBD1 and FBD2, were retrieved ( Zhang et al., 2014a, Zhang et al., 2014b), with FBD1 representing a novel parvovirus species ( Lau et al., 2012a, Cotmore et al., 2014). Also, a cyclovirus (ssDNA) (family Circoviridae) strain, FD, was identified. Upon sequence and phylogenetic analysis, the virus differed from other cyclovirus species ( Zhang et al., 2014a, Zhang et al., 2014b). Cycloviruses have been found recently in different biological samples from a number of host species, including mammals and insects ( Li et al., 2010a, Li et al., 2010b, Ge et al., 2011, Rosario et al., 2011, Dayaram et al., 2013, Padilla-Rodriguez et al., 2013, Phan et al., 2014).
